author: Special Correspondent
text:
The State BJP on Sunday held its first social media workshop to strengthen its campaign for the upcoming Assembly polls in Tamil Nadu, with localisation of content being the focus.

The meeting also saw party MP and national spokesperson Meenakshi Lekhi exhorting the participants to be vigilant against “motivated and unnecessary” criticism on the Centre and counter them real time.

The closed-door meeting saw about 500 attendees. Party media committee head S.R. Sekar said the plan was to identify volunteers to take forward the social media campaign in all 234 constituencies. “We will group the volunteers according to constituencies and have localised content. This way, we believe we could connect better with the voters and take up issues that affect them on a daily basis,” he added. Referring to the widespread criticism of the Centre after the Dadri lynching episode, Ms. Lekhi said what was a mishandling of a law and order situation by the Uttar Pradesh State government quickly became a tool to bash the BJP. “We have to expose such misinformation,” she said.

Jallikattu not political move

Addressing a press conference later, Ms. Lekhi said revival of the popular bull taming sport, jallikattu was not a political move aimed at garnering votes. Rather, it was to ensure that the culture of Tamil Nadu was protected and sentiments of Tamils were respected. She said the suggestion of have observers from the Centre to ensure zero cruelty to animals would be considered and taken to the relevant authorities.

Party holds first social media workshop to strengthen its campaign
title: BJP to localise social media campaign
